title: Temple Worship Instructions
shortSummary: Ezekiel 46 provides detailed instructions concerning the worship practices in the restored temple, focusing on the prince's role, offerings on Sabbaths and new moons, and the proper handling of sacrifices. The chapter emphasizes orderly worship, the prince’s responsibility, and the sanctity of the temple precincts, reflecting God's desire for holiness and reverence in worship.
timeline: c. 6th century BC - Babylonian Exile, during Ezekiel's prophetic ministry

keyCharacters.name: The Prince
keyCharacters.description: A leader figure who has specific responsibilities in temple worship, including offering sacrifices and entering through designated gates.

keyCharacters.name: The Priests
keyCharacters.description: Temple ministers who prepare and offer sacrifices on behalf of the prince and the people, ensuring proper worship.

keyCharacters.name: The People of the Land
keyCharacters.description: The worshippers who come to the temple on Sabbaths, new moons, and solemn feasts to worship the LORD.

definitions.definition: A unit of dry measure used in ancient Israel, roughly equivalent to about 22 liters or 2/3 of a bushel.
A unit of liquid measure used in the Old Testament, approximately 3.7 liters or about one gallon.
A sacrifice wholly consumed by fire on the altar, symbolizing atonement and dedication to God.
A voluntary sacrifice expressing thanksgiving, fellowship, and reconciliation with God.

outline.heading: Gate Regulations for Worship
outline.description: Instructions on the opening and closing of the eastern gate of the inner court, specifying that it remains shut on working days but opens on Sabbaths and new moons for worship.

outline.heading: Sacrificial Offerings of the Prince
outline.description: Details the specific burnt offerings and meat offerings the prince must present on Sabbaths, new moons, and voluntary occasions, emphasizing the need for offerings without blemish.

outline.heading: Daily Burnt Offering
outline.description: Commands the continual daily burnt offering of a lamb without blemish every morning, accompanied by a meat offering and oil, establishing a perpetual ordinance.

outline.heading: Inheritance Laws for the Prince
outline.description: Regulations concerning the prince’s gifts and inheritance, prohibiting him from oppressing the people or taking their land, ensuring justice and stability.

outline.heading: Priestly Chambers and Sacrificial Preparation
outline.description: Description of the priests’ chambers and designated places for boiling sin and trespass offerings, as well as baking meat offerings, maintaining ritual cleanliness and order.

application: Approach worship with reverence and obedience, honoring God’s appointed times and ways as shown in the temple regulations.
Recognize the importance of leadership in spiritual responsibilities, following the example of the prince who offers sacrifices on behalf of the people.
Commit to daily devotion and continual offerings of praise to God, reflecting the daily burnt offering prescribed in the chapter.
Respect God’s justice by honoring the rights and possessions of others, avoiding oppression and selfish gain.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the Lord GOD; The gate of the inner court that looketh toward the east shall be shut the six working days; but on the sabbath it shall be opened, and in the day of the new moon it shall be opened.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the sacredness of the Sabbath and new moon days as special times for worship and access to God’s presence.

keyVerses.text: Thou shalt daily prepare a burnt offering unto the LORD of a lamb of the first year without blemish: thou shalt prepare it every morning.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the importance of continual, daily dedication and atonement before God.

keyVerses.text: Moreover the prince shall not take of the people's inheritance by oppression, to thrust them out of their possession; but he shall give his sons inheritance out of his own possession: that my people be not scattered every man from his possession.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the principle of just leadership and respect for the rights of God’s people.
